#Text=Calatafimi Segesta
#Text=Calatafimi Segesta is in Sicily .
#Text=Understand

#Text=The town takes its name from the Arab " Qal’at Fimi " ( that is Rock of Eufemio ) : he was an officer of Byzantium who , according to an old tradition , favoured the conquest of Sicily by the Saracens .
#Text=Some scholars link the name Calatafimi with Acesta , a little town contemporary of Segesta , or with Castrum Phimes , from the name of a noble landowner of Segesta , named also by Cicero .
#Text=The present town originated around the “ Castle of Phimes ” , and its oldest part stands here .
#Text=Calatafimi , with the Castle of Eufemio and its churches , is characterised also by its lanes and small streets of Arab derivation .
#Text=At about 10 km from this town there is the archaeological site of Segesta , with the Greek temple and the ancient theatre , where they hold classical performances .
#Text=Tourist Information
#Text=Ufficio Turistico , piazza Cangemi,1 , ☏ +3909249505507 , fax : +3909249505515 , ✉ affarigenerali@comune.calatafimisegesta.tp.it .
#Text=Pro Loco , Corso Vittorio Emanuele,16 , ☏ +393339245687 , ✉ prolococalatafimisegesta@gmail.com .
#Text=U.R.P. ( Public Relations Office ) , Piazza Francesco Cangemi,1 , ☏ +3909249505240 , ✉ urp@pec.comune.calatafimisegesta.tp.it .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Calatafimi is about 60 km from Aeroporto " Falcone e Borsellino " of Palermo-Punta Raisi and 50 km from Aeroporto " Vincenzo Florio " of Trapani-Birgi ( phone : +390923842502 ) .

column1: #Text=From Airport Palermo-Punta Raisi , you can get the train from Punta Raisi to Alcamo Diramazione railway station ( one every 30 minutes ) and take a taxi from there .
#Text=By car
#Text=From Palermo — Through the A29 Motorway Palermo-Trapani , at Segesta exit , after passing the archaelogical area , you enter the National Road 113 ( S.S.113 ) towards Trapani .
#Text=The junction for Calatafimi is at about 3 Km .
#Text=From Trapani — Through the A29 Motorway , towards Palermo , at Segesta exit ; otherwise you can go along the National Road 113 and take the junction after those for Vita and Pianto Romano .
#Text=By ship
#Text=Linea Tirrenia ( Cagliari-Trapani ) , ☏ +390923545433 .
#Text=Linea Grimaldi ( Tunisi-Trapani ) , ☏ +390923542470 .
#Text=Linea Ustica Lines ( Livorno-Trapani ) , ☏ +390923873813 .
#Text=Siremar ( Isole Egadi e Pantelleria ) , ☏ +39092324968 .
#Text=Traghetti delle Isole , via Ammiraglio Staiti , 23 ( Trapani
#Text=) .
#Text=Ustica Lines ( Aliscafo per Isole Egadi , Pantelleria , Ustica e Napoli ) , ☏ +390923873813 .
#Text=By rail
#Text=Railway Station of Alcamo Diramazione ( At about 9 km from the town , near the junction Alcamo Ovest A29 Motorway ) .
#Text=It is on the railway line Palermo-Trapani .
#Text=By bus
#Text=AST ( Azienda Siciliana Trasporti ) , via Virgilio , 20 Trapani ( Palermo
#Text=Autoservizi Lumia ( Agrigento-Trapani ) ( Palermo
#Text=Autoservizi Salemi ( Roma - Trapani ) ( Palermo
#Text=Segesta autolinee ( Palermo - Trapani ) , Via Libertà , 171 ( Palermo
#Text=Segesta autolinee ( Roma - Trapani ) , Via Libertà , 171 ( Palermo
#Text=Tarantola bus , Via Marina Petrolo , 16 ( Castellammare del Golfo ) , ☏ +39092431020 , ✉ info@tarantolabus.it .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Owing to the particular geographical position of Calatafimi , many streets have a steep slope .
#Text=Moreover , Eufemio Castle and the Church of Santissimo Crocifisso are two perfect points of reference as they are visible from different places .

#Text=After going uphill for Via Segesta ( take the ingresso della cittadina if you are coming from the National Road 113 ) , you get to largo Duca degli Abruzzi which is the right starting point for any exploration .
#Text=On the left there is Via Alcide de Gasperi ( an almost new area ) , while the main road link is corso Garibaldi , on the right .
#Text=From via Marconi , an important main road which continues to Corso Vittorio Emanuele , you will arrive at piazza Plebiscito and can start an artistic tour of the town .

#Text=Here you can admire the Church of Madonna di Giubino , built by Giovan Biagio Amico from Trapani , close to the 16th-century small church of the Benedictine nunnery of Santa Caterina , and , on the other side of the square , the Church of San Michele , with the Civic Library on its right .

#Text=Further on , along via Marconi , you will meet the Town Hall ( Palazzo Comunale ) , between palazzo Pampalone , where the hero of the Risorgimento ( 19th-century struggle for Italian unification ) , Garibaldi rested after the battle of Pianto Romano , and the 16th-century church of San Giuliano .
#Text=From via Marconi you will arrive at piazza Nocito and , behind it , piazza Nullo .
#Text=At the end of the slope , there is the mother Church of San Silvestro Papa , and , if you go on climbing , you get to the hill ’s peak ( 338 metres high ) where Eufemio Castle rises .
#Text=Coming down viale Oberdan you will find the medieval quarter of Borgo ( the old village ) , that keeps integral its environmental features inside the small streets and courtyards .
#Text=Taxi service
#Text=As the town centre of Calatafimi is quite small and its streets are narrow , there is no bus service , so you can walk , or for long distances , you can use your car or get a taxi .
#Text=Nstonline Transfer & Taxi , Via Segesta , 34 , ☎ +39 366 8710222 .
#Text=Segesta archaeological site
#Text=Segesta is the site of an ancient Graeco - Roman city .
#Text=The site is immediately off the main A29 road , straight after a long tunnel if travelling from Palermo .
#Text=Onsite there is free parking .
#Text=Tarantola Bus goes between Palermo and Calatafimi ( aka Calatafimi-Segesta ) a few times daily , stopping at Segesta en route .
#Text=You may have a long wait for a return bus .
#Text=( Perhaps confusingly , Segesta Bus does not go to Segesta . )
#Text=Entry to the temple is on foot - about a 5-minute uphill walk .
#Text=A bus ( € 1.50 ) is available every 30 minutes to the site of the Amphitheatre at the top of the hill .
#Text=It 's a brisk , uphill , 20-minute walk otherwise ( no entrance fee ) .
#Text=Coffee and pizza are well deserved at the cafe near the car park if you walked to the amphitheatre .
#Text=There are 3 major sights at this location , and there are other remains from the Roman and medieval periods which are documented by signs in five languages across the site .
#Text=The Doric temple , Archaelogical area of Segesta .

#Text=Built between 430-420 BCE , 61 m ( 190 feet ) long , 26 m wide , built upon a platform of 4 steps , it has 36 Doric columns supporting the stone roof-frame of the structure ( 14 columns along the lengths of the building , 6 columns across front and back ) .
#Text=They are of a " rough " finish as the temple has never been completed .

#Text=The temple seems also to have lacked a roof over the cella ( main chamber ) in antiquity , rather uniquely - scholars are in disagreement as to whether the temple was planned this way , or just never completed .
#Text=Entry is charged .
#Text=The Greek Amphitheatre .
#Text=It is on a hilltop and was built by the Greeks at about 400 BC .
#Text=It was discovered in the 19th century .
#Text=They play classical comedies and tragedies in July and August .
#Text=The Greek sanctuary , contrada Mango ( on the Provincial Road leading to Segesta ) .
#Text=In the archaeological area of Segesta there are the remains of an ancient sanctuary , dating back perhaps to the 6th century BC and built outside the town centre of Segesta .
